parent_formation: British First Army (designated, not yet deployed)

supply_logistics.supply_status: EXCELLENT - Division at full war establishment strength in England preparing for overseas deployment. Completed Exercise Dryshod (amphibious landing training) in August 1942. Final preparation at Aldershot in December 1942. Inspected by King George VI. Embarking from Liverpool (24 Dec) and Scotland (6 Jan) for Operation Torch follow-on forces. Full complement of equipment and supplies loaded for North Africa deployment.

weather_environment.terrain_type: England - Training grounds at Aldershot and Kent. Division preparing for North Africa deployment but still in UK during Q4 1942. Embarkation began 24 December 1942 from Liverpool.

subordinate_units.note: Joined division 15 August 1942, replacing 137th Brigade. Battalions: 1/4th Hampshire Regiment, 2/4th Hampshire Regiment, 5th Hampshire Regiment. Departed Scotland 6 January 1943.
Battalions: 6th Lincolnshire Regiment, 2/4th King's Own Yorkshire Light Infantry, 6th York and Lancaster Regiment. Departed Liverpool 6 January 1943.
Battalions: 2/5th Leicestershire Regiment, 2/5th Sherwood Foresters, 9th Sherwood Foresters. Part of first contingent departing Liverpool 24 December 1942.

tactical_doctrine.role: Infantry division preparing for deployment to North Africa as reinforcement for British First Army in Tunisia Campaign. Division training focused on amphibious operations (Exercise Dryshod) and combined arms warfare for Mediterranean theater.
special_capabilities: North Midland Territorial division with strong regional cohesion
Amphibious landing training completed (Exercise Dryshod, August 1942)
Full war establishment strength with modern equipment
Fresh troops at peak readiness for overseas deployment
King George VI inspection in December 1942 - high morale
tactical_innovations: Trained for amphibious operations despite not participating in initial Torch landings
Prepared for Mediterranean/Tunisian terrain rather than Western Desert
Combined arms integration with full divisional support elements
known_issues: No combat experience - Territorial division that had not yet seen action
Exercise Dryshod casualties (15 killed, 30 injured in truck accident, August 1942)
Long sea journey ahead (Liverpool to Algiers, ~2 weeks)
Would arrive in Tunisia after initial battles, mid-campaign
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: NOT APPLICABLE - Division still in England during Q4 1942. Preparing for North Africa deployment but training in UK conditions. Would arrive Tunisia January 1943 (not desert terrain, but Tunisian hills/farmland).

scenario_suitability: Hypothetical UK defense scenarios (what-if German invasion)
wargaming_data.experience_level: Green (no combat experience as of Q4 1942)
special_rules: Fresh troops bonus (full strength, high morale, modern equipment)
historical_engagements: Embarkation for North Africa (24 December 1942 - 6 January 1943)

source: British Military History - Tunisia 1942-1943 British Infantry Divisions
WebSearch - 46th Division North Midland brigade structure Tunisia
Standard British infantry division war establishment 1942
required_field_gaps: exact equipment allocations (estimated from war establishment)

chief_of_staff.name.reason: Chief of Staff name not found in available sources for 1942
chief_of_staff.name.mitigation: UK National Archives or divisional war diaries

brigade_commanders.reason: None of the three brigade commanders' names documented in available sources for 1942
brigade_commanders.mitigation: Regimental histories or UK National Archives

equipment_allocations.reason: Specific equipment counts not found - estimated from standard British infantry division war establishment 1942
equipment_allocations.estimate_method: Standard British infantry division war establishment 1942: 17,298 personnel, 72x 25-pdrs, 48x AT guns (6-pdr standard by late 1942), ~3,200 vehicles
equipment_allocations.mitigation: Access War Office records or divisional logistics documentation

divisional_support_units.reason: Specific designations of divisional artillery regiments, engineer units, signals not documented
divisional_support_units.mitigation: Divisional operational orders or UK National Archives

notes: CRITICAL: Q4 1942 (Oct-Dec) - Division was STILL IN ENGLAND preparing for deployment
Division departed Liverpool 24 December 1942 (end of quarter)
Arrived Algeria 3 January 1943, reached Tunisia frontline 17 January 1943
First combat would be in 1943-Q1, NOT in 1942-Q4
North Midland Territorial division - battalions from English North Midlands
Inspected by King George VI at Aldershot, December 1942
137th Brigade departed 19 July 1942, replaced by 128th Brigade 15 August 1942
No combat experience as of end of 1942-Q4
Tier 2 classification due to estimated equipment and missing commander/staff names
Equipment based on standard British infantry division war establishment 1942

commander.name: Major-General Harold Freeman-Attwood
commander.previous_service: Took command November 1941, replacing Major-General Miles Dempsey
